newsitem.title: USA: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS - prices end flat to higher.
newsitem.headline: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS - prices end flat to higher.

text.p: U.S. municipal bond cash prices ended flat to higher selectively, while muni futures ended between 1/4 and 3/8 of a point higher.

"Retail is not snapping (bonds) up, and customers keep selling bonds," one trader said, adding, however, that selling was less brisk than Tuesday's. The trader judged the market unchanged to up 1/8 point in spots.
A municipal analyst said dollar bonds were up 1/8 point, while high-grade issues improved slightly. Overall, the market was flat to up 1/4 point in light to moderate activity, he said.
In debt futures the September municipal contract closed up 10/32 at 114-27/32. The September T-bond contract closed down 5/32 at 108-25/32. The MOB spread was 194 ticks.
In the government market, the benchmark 30-year bond ended down 3/32 at 97-3/32 to yield 6.98 percent.

Municipal market activity is expected to slow as the Labor Day weekend nears, a trader said. The Public Securities Association has recommended a 1400 EDT early close Friday for municipals and U.S. government bonds as well as several other markets.

In new issues, Smith Barney Inc said it repriced $395 million New York State Dormitory Authority bonds, lowering yields in several maturities and cutting the top yield in 2026 to 6.23 percent from 6.25 percent.

"I thought it was a pretty reasonable pricing," Tony Tanner, an assistant portfolio manager at Oppenheimer Funds, said. "This is the first large-scale deal in the New York market in two weeks, so certainly that made a difference in terms of how aggressive they were going to be."
On some occasions involving borrowers "of this large a stature," underwriters will jump out with aggressive pricing at the start, Tanner said.
"In this case they priced the bonds appropriately and got enough of a book to fill it and have a slight price adjustment," he said.
Tanner said he heard the 2022 and 2026 maximum-yield term bonds received "strong interest."
"Here, we thought the bonds priced in 2010 were particularly attractive," he said.
"They were a six percent coupon to yield 6.05 percent, which is a good yield for that kind of 14-year intermediate term," he said.
Oppenheimer put in for some of those 2010 bonds for its $645 million Limited Term New York Municipal Fund, Tanner said.
Thomas Devane, the Dormitory Authority's deputy executive director, said the sale went "very well."

"We had three different series of bonds," he said. "We had some insured bonds, we had some serials, we had some term bonds and I think we had a menu there for just about any kind of buyer that wanted to come in."
While a few serials remained, some term bonds were three times oversubscribed, Devane said.
"I don't think there is going to be any hang over," he said. "The bonds will be going away probably by Friday."
The deal was on somewhat of a tight time schedule, Devane said. It was slotted for late August, he said, adding that frames are set to keep state appropriation deals from running too close together.

However, because an illness at the City University of New York system delayed a quorem until Monday morning, the preliminary offering statement could not be released until Monday afternoon, Devane said.
The Authority asked lead manager Smith Barney to give retail buyers priority, and to help identify them, the underwriter asked that zip codes accompany such orders, Devane said.
--Kathie O'Donnell, 212-859-1655
